# TVContentIdentifier

**Class**

An object that uniquely identifies media content in either a single piece or a collection.

## Declaration

```swift
class TVContentIdentifier
```

## Overview

Every content identifier is represented by two parts: a string identifier ([doc://com.apple.tvservices/documentation/TVServices/TVContentIdentifier/identifier]) and a container identifier ([doc://com.apple.tvservices/documentation/TVServices/TVContentIdentifier/container]). The container identifier may be `nil`, which indicates that the content lives at the top level of the container hierarchy. You are responsible for organizing your content into a hierarchy and creating identifiers that uniquely identify each piece of content.

When designing your content identifiers, follow this guidance:

- A given content identifier must be unique for a particular content item, across *all* past, current, and future content items, even if the user no longer has access to that item.
- The uniqueness of a content identifier comes from the uniqueness of its two parts. The [doc://com.apple.tvservices/documentation/TVServices/TVContentIdentifier/identifier] property of a content identifier need not be universally unique across all of the app’s content identifiers, as long as items that share the same identifier string are contained in different containers.

## Initializing a Content Identifier

- **init(identifier:container:)**: Creates a new content identifier.
- **init(coder:)**: Returns an object initialized from data in a given unarchiver.

## Inspecting an Identifier’s Contents

- **identifier**: The string that identifies this content item.
- **container**: The container that this content item is contained in.

## Content

- **TVContentItem**: An object that describes either a piece of content or a container for other content items.
- **TVTopShelfImageSize(shape:style:)**: Returns the ideal size for an image, according to its particular shape and style.
